Key Arguments: The bill undermines freedom of speech and democratic values.
It creates two classes of citizens, unfairly targeting ordinary citizens.
Judging truth is difficult, and authorities can be wrong, as shown in past public health debates.
The bill targets both false and true information that could be misleading, stifling open discussion.
Free market competition between platforms can naturally address misinformation without regulation.
The bill's extraterritorial application is problematic and could alienate Australia globally.
It interferes with political communication and limits access to diverse viewpoints.
The bill imposes threats and penalties that discourage public discourse, resembling authoritarian regimes.
Notable Quotes: The existence of this bill demonstrates a lack of respect for the freedom of speech of Australian citizens.
History has shown that even authorities and expert consensus can sometimes be incorrect.
The bill's threats and penalties imposed on digital platform providers and ordinary users are an affront to freedom of expression and personal liberties.
